newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy govt calls confidence vote on budget package.
newsitem.headline: Italy govt calls confidence vote on budget package.

text.p: The Italian government on Monday called a confidence vote in the lower house of parliament to sweep aside opposition amendments to a batch of measures included in its 1997 budget.

The package, designed to raise around 4.3 trillion lire ($2.59 billion) this year, was introduced by a cabinet decree at the end of December and now needs parliamentary approval to become full legislation.
But the measures have been weighed down by hundreds of amendments and Finance Minister Vincenzo Visco asked parliament to hold a do-or-die confidence vote to ram the decree into law.
Parliamentary party leaders were due to decide later on Monday when the vote would be held and state television said it would probably take place on Tuesday.
Prime Minister Romano Prodi's centre-left coalition relies on the hardleft Communist Refoundation for its majority in the Chamber of Deputies (lower house).

Refoundation has previously given broad backing to the year-end package of measures, which formed the final part of the government's massive 1997 budget, designed to cut 62.5 trillion lire off the state deficit.
Parliamentarians from Communist Refoundation abstained in a brief vote held to accept Visco's request.
"We abstained because we were neither convinced by the need for this nor against it," Refoundation's parliamentary party leader, Oliviero Diliberto, said.

Prodi called numerous confidence motions in both the upper and lower houses of parliament last year to brush past opposition filibustering on a wide range of legislation, winning all the votes with ease.

The end-of-year package expected to raise some two trillion lire in 1997 by forcing companies to speed up payments of certain excise duties -- mainly on mineral oils, alcoholic beverages, methane gas and electricity.
It also included measures against tax evasion and included incentives to scrap cars more than 10 years old in an effort to boost the flagging auto sector.

Prodi and Treasury Minister Carlo Azeglio Ciampi are now working on a fresh budget package to be unveiled shortly in a bid to mop up an overshoot in 1996 accounts. The government is expected to introduce deficit-cutting measures worth around 15 trillion lire.
Refoundation has already warned that it will not support any fresh tax increases or new reductions state spending.
